section.title: Introduction
section.para: RFC 4890 is entitled "Recommendations for Filtering ICMPv6 Messages in Firewalls".
The recommendations pertain to firewalling at router level, not necessarily hosts or bridges (which may need to treat some packets differently, e.g. NS/NA and RS/RA).
It is assumed that a policy of reject or deny is in place. If that is not the case then some packet types need dropping explicitly to meet the recommendations.

section.title: Allow outbound echo requests from prefixes which belong to the site
section.para: The router command (see ) should be used with an appropriate src rule parameter (see ).

section.title: Allow inbound echo requests towards only predetermined hosts
section.para: The should be used in combination with an appropriate dst rule parameter (see ).

section.title: Allow incoming and outgoing echo reply messages only for existing sessions
section.para: This is handled automatically by the .

section.title: Deny icmps to/from link local addresses
section.para: The router command (see ) should be used with an appropriate src and dst rule parameter (see ). For example: src not "${UNROUTABLE_IPS}" dst not "${UNROUTABLE_IPS}"

section.title: Drop echo replies which have a multicast address as a destination
section.para:
The can be used with an appropriate src rule parameter (see ). For example: ipv6 route ping src not "${MULTICAST6_IPS}"
will prevent incoming echo-requests from multicast IPs and replies to them.

section.title: Allow incoming destination unreachable messages only for existing sessions
section.para:
Ensure any routers have: server ipv6error accept
Adding dst "$inner_prefix" ensures only public hosts receive the messages. See .

note.para: Note: in the example RFC script, non-established/related messages are allowed through for this type.
It is not clear why since code 0 and not code 1 messages are listed as part of the establishment of communications. Code 1 messages are listed as less essential for propagation over the network.
The behaviour implemented here is as per destination unreachable messages, so the same as the incoming time exceeded code 0 messages example.

section.title: Allow incoming and outgoing parameter problem code 0 messages
section.para: From the RFC it is not really necessary to allow these messages. FireHOL handles this automatically (by dropping them) unless you create a rule to explicitly allow the packets using the icmpv6 type bad-header.

section.title: Drop NS/NA messages both incoming and outgoing
section.para: FireHOL handles this automatically unless you set up an explicit route for the packets.

note.para: Hosts and bridges need to allow these messages. See .

section.title: Drop Redirect messages both incoming and outgoing
section.para: FireHOL handles this automatically unless you set up an explicit route for the packets.

note.para: At some point FireHOL may have a helper command added to simplify allowing these messages on a host/bridge. Meantime this is an example of the relevant ip6tables command: ip6tables -A icmpv6-filter -p icmpv6 --icmpv6-type redirect -j DROP

section.title: If there are mobile ipv6 home agents present on the trusted side allow
section.para: At some point FireHOL may have a helper command added to simplify this setup. Meantime this is an example of the relevant ip6tables commands from the RFC script: #incoming Home Agent address discovery request ip6tables -A icmpv6-filter -p icmpv6 -d $inner_prefix \ --icmpv6-type 144 -j ACCEPT #outgoing Home Agent address discovery reply ip6tables -A icmpv6-filter -p icmpv6 -s $inner_prefix \ --icmpv6-type 145 -j ACCEPT #incoming Mobile prefix solicitation ip6tables -A icmpv6-filter -p icmpv6 -d $inner_prefix \ --icmpv6-type 146 -j ACCEPT #outgoing Mobile prefix advertisement ip6tables -A icmpv6-filter -p icmpv6 -s $inner_prefix \ --icmpv6-type 147 -j ACCEPT

section.title: If there are roaming mobile nodes present on the trusted side allow
